text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section do you know what you're making
for Christmas dinner because I know what
I'm making for Christmas dinner crown
roast of pork you need an excuse to make
a crown roast of pork because it's
expensive but it's impressive so what's
a better excuse than Christmas a crown
roast of pork is basically a pork loin
with the ribs and your butcher uses
string to tie it together to make it
look like a crown you're gonna need
about one rib per person or it may be
one and a half ribs per person it
depends on what else you're serving the
thing about a crown roast is that it has
so much flavor on its own it doesn't
need more than salt and pepper however I
am gonna gild the lily and I'm gonna
make an herb paste with sage fennel seed
lemon zest and garlic to get the most
flavor out of the fennel seeds I'm gonna
toast them for about a minute once you
can smell the fennel seeds they're ready
you just want to bring out their
essential oils and when you can smell
them you know that you've done that I'm
just gonna throw all the herbs into the
blender to make the herb paste but you
could also use a mortar and pestle so
I'm gonna add five chopped up garlic
cloves some sage leaves the zest of a
lemon
those fennel seeds that we just toasted
rosemary olive oil salt and my secret
ingredient fennel pollen fennel pollen
adds an intense fennel flavor and it's
the kind of thing where if you happen to
have some in your spice cabinet and you
think what could I use fennel pollen for
this is what you can use it for if you
don't have it just leave it out for the
exact recipe go to nytimes.com slash
dining score a pit down make sure it's
even when it's done it should look like
pesto I've got a 9 pound crown roast
here so I'm gonna use a tablespoon of
course kosher salt and a lot of black
pepper to season it then I'm gonna rub
it down with the herb paste don't forget
to season in the middle smear it with
paste and there's no other way to do it
than your hands
it's just messy just the way it is you
really want to work the paste into these
little cuts that the butcher made so
that your flavoring all parts of the
meat don't forget about the bottom if
you have time you really want to
marinate this thing overnight in the
fridge if you don't have time
two hours of room temperature will do
there are two schools of thought for
cooking a crown roast you could roast it
with the ribs down or the ribs up most
people do it with the ribs up but the
problem is that these ribs often start
to burn and get black which is why
people put those funny little hats on
their crown roast which is not my
favorite look so what I do is I flip it
over I roast it with the ribs down the
juices that are dripping from the roast
protects them keeps them from turning
black and you have the added benefit of
see all that nice fat if you roast it
fat side up the fat gets brown and
crispy yum then just set it down in a
roasting pan and put a rack on the
bottom that helps steady it if you don't
have a rack you don't need one I'm gonna
start the roast at 450 to get it nice
and brown for about 20 minutes then
reduce the heat to 350 and finish it off
about an hour and a half you want the
internal temperature to read 145 and
here you go did this one earlier so you
see how nice and brown and crisp all
that fats gotten YUM
and then to serve it you just want to
flip it over
I never stuffed my crown roasts stuffing
a crown roast of pork is just like
stuffing a turkey it's gonna slow down
the cooking it's gonna make it cook
unevenly and then you have to worry
about the stuffing coming up to
temperature before carving you want to
get rid of the butchers twine just cut
it off of the knife and then you just
cut between each rib and give each
person a nice
twice
